questions.question: Why is using a fixed seed (or equivalent) useful when iterating?
options: It improves repeatability so you can measure changes
It forces the model to follow facts
questions.answer: It improves repeatability so you can measure changes
questions.explanation: Repeatability helps you attribute differences to a prompt/setting change instead of randomness.

questions.question: A constraint-first workflow can help produce more consistent images.
questions.explanation: Constraining composition/identity reduces degrees of freedom and improves consistency.

questions.question: What’s a good strategy to improve consistency across a set?
options: Vary only one variable at a time
Change subject, style, and camera all at once
questions.answer: Vary only one variable at a time
questions.explanation: Controlling variables reduces drift and makes it easier to debug why a set doesn’t match.

questions.question: Which are common image generation failure modes?
questions.explanation: Artifacts, drift, and leakage are common; accuracy guarantees don’t exist for generative outputs.

questions.question: What is a targeted edit (inpainting-style) best used for?
options: Fixing a localized flaw without changing the whole image
questions.answer: Fixing a localized flaw without changing the whole image
questions.explanation: Targeted edits let you preserve what works and fix only the broken region.

questions.question: Keeping a written log of changes helps you build a repeatable workflow.
questions.explanation: Logging prompts/settings turns trial-and-error into a process you can repeat and improve.
